feature.name: Adlivun Cavus
feature.origin: Underworld in Inuit myths.

feature.name: Alcyonia Lacus
feature.origin: A bottomless lake, one of the entrances to the underworld in Greek mythology.

feature.name: Al-Idrisi Montes
feature.origin: Ash-Sharīf al-Idrīsī; Arabian mapmaker and geographer (1100–1165/66).

feature.name: Baret Montes
feature.origin: Jeanne Baret (Baré); first woman to have completed circumnavigation voyage of the globe (1740-1807).

feature.name: Burney
feature.origin: Venetia; British schoolgirl, who suggested in 1930 the name “Pluto” for Tombaugh’s newly discovered planet (1918–2009).

feature.name: Coughlin
feature.origin: Thomas Boyd; American mechanical/space engineer, first project manager of the New Horizons mission to Pluto and the Kuiper Belt (1941–2014).

feature.name: Djanggawul Fossae
feature.origin: Ancestral beings in Yolngu (Australia) myth who traveled between the island of the dead and Australia.

feature.name: Elcano Montes
feature.origin: Juan Sebastián; Spanish explorer of Basque origin, who completed in 1522 the first circumnavigation of the Earth which started in 1519 under the leadership of Magellan (c.1476–1526).

feature.name: Elliot
feature.origin: James; American astronomer, discoverer of the atmosphere of Pluto (1943–2011).

feature.name: Hardie
feature.origin: Robert H.; American astronomer, co-discoverer (1955) of Pluto’s 6.4-day rotation period (1923–1989).

feature.name: Hayabusa Terra
feature.origin: Japanese Hayabusa (literally Peregrine Falcon) spacecraft that performed the first asteroid sample return (2003–2010).

feature.name: Hekla Cavus
feature.origin: An Icelandic volcano believed to be the entrance to Hell in medieval European times.

feature.name: Hermod Fossae
feature.origin: Son of Odin, who rode the horse Sleipnir into the underworld to retrieve his brother, Balder.

feature.name: Hillary Montes
feature.origin: Edmund; New Zealand mountaineer (1919–2008).

feature.name: Hunahpu Valles
feature.origin: One of the Hero Twins (with Xbalanque) in Mayan mythology, who defeated the lords of the Underworld in a ball game.

feature.name: Hyecho Palus
feature.origin: Korean traveler and scholar, who crossed the Asian continent from China to Arabia and back (724-727), and documented the journey in his journals (704–787).

feature.name: Kaknú Fossa
feature.origin: Epic hero of the Chochenyo/Ohlone (N. California) mythology, an anthropomorphic being resembling a peregrine falcon, who traveled to the underworld to battle Wiwe (“Body of Stone”), the lord of the underworld.

feature.name: Khare
feature.origin: Bishun; Indian-born American atmosphere chemistry scientist, investigated, in particular, tholins, the organic molecules that probably account for the darkest regions on Pluto (1933–2013).

feature.name: Kiladze
feature.origin: Rolan; Georgian (Caucasus) astronomer. Investigated the dynamics, astrometry and photometry of Pluto (1931–2010).

feature.name: Lowell Regio
feature.origin: Percival; American astronomer who in 1906-1916 undertook extensive searches of transneptunian planets (1855-1916).

feature.name: Mwindo Fossae
feature.origin: Nyanga (Eastern Dem. Rep. Congo/Zaire) epic hero who travelled to the underworld and after returning home became a wise and powerful king.

feature.name: Piccard Mons
feature.origin: Auguste; Swiss-Belgian inventor and physicist known for his pioneering balloon flights into the Earth’s upper atmosphere up to 17 km (1884–1962).

feature.name: Pigafetta Montes
feature.origin: Antonio; Italian scholar and explorer, whose journal is the only original description of the discoveries made during the first circumnavigation of the Earth which started in Spain in 1519 under the leadership of Magellan (c.1491 – c.1531).

feature.name: Piri Rupes
feature.origin: Ahmed Muhiddin, also known as Piri Reis, Ottoman navigator and cartographer (c. 1470–1553). Author of one of the earliest existing world maps in 1513. His “Book of the Sea” (1521), containing 290 maps, was one of the most famous cartographical works of that period.

feature.name: Simonelli
feature.origin: Damon; American astronomer; investigated the formation history of Pluto (1959–2004).

feature.name: Sleipnir Fossa
feature.origin: A powerful, eight-legged horse in Norse mythology who carried Odin into the Underworld.

feature.name: Sputnik Planitia
feature.origin: Soviet Union's Sputnik 1 (literally Satellite 1), the first human-built satellite of the Earth (1957).

feature.name: Tabei Montes
feature.origin: Junko Tabei, Japanese mountaineer and the first woman to climb both Mount Everest and the Seven Summits (1939–2016).

feature.name: Tartarus Dorsa
feature.origin: The deepest, darkest pit of the Underworld in Greek mythology.

feature.name: Tenzing Montes
feature.origin: Tenzing Norgay; Nepalese (Sherpa) mountaineer (1914–1986).

feature.name: Tombaugh Regio
feature.origin: Clyde William; American astronomer, discoverer of Pluto (1906–1997).

feature.name: Uncama Fossa
feature.origin: Zulu tale hero, who followed a porcupine underground and came upon the village of dead souls.

feature.name: Vega Terra
feature.origin: A pair of the Soviet Union’s Vega 1 and Vega 2 spacecraft launched in 1984 that were the first ones to fly balloons on another planet (Venus, 1985) and then the first ones to image the nucleus of a comet (1P/Halley, 1986).

feature.name: Venera Terra
feature.origin: Series of the Soviet Union’s 16 spacecraft sent to Venus in 1961–1983. The missions accomplished a number of firsts, including the first human made device to enter the atmosphere of another planet (Venera 3, 1966), to measure in situ atmosphere composition of another planet (Venera 4, 1967), to make a soft landing on another planet (Venera 7, 1970), and to return images from another planetary surface (Venera 9, 1975).

feature.name: Virgil Fossae
feature.origin: Italian; Dante’s guide through Hell and Purgatory in the Divine Comedy of Dante Alighieri (1265–1321).

feature.name: Voyager Terra
feature.origin: A pair of US-launched Voyager 1 and Voyager 2 spacecraft that performed the “grand tour” of all four giant planets (1977-1989).

feature.name: Wright Mons
feature.origin: Orville (1871–1948) and Wilbur (1867–1912), brothers, U.S. aviation pioneers who invented, built, and flew in 1903 the world’s first successful powered heavier-than-air flying machine (airplane) with a pilot aboard.
